title: Zero Carbon Britain: Live online
excerpt: Online Zero Carbon Britain course exploring climate solutions – the science says we must, the technology says we can, time to say we will! Working with a range of local…

title: Interactive webinar: Tried and tested solutions for a green recovery – Renewable energy
excerpt: Explore local renewable energy solutions and hear from experts sharing their practical experiences of local authority innovation in this field.

title: Online sustainable energy discussion forum
cat_header: A loose discussion group for professionals and experts interested in diverse aspects of the sustainable energy world.

title: Salix Finance
cat_header: Provides Government funding to the public sector to improve energy efficiency, reduce carbon emissions and lower energy bills.
detail_from_source: Salix is a non-departmental public body, owned wholly by Government. Salix is funded by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, the Department for Education, the Welsh Government and the Scottish Government. They currently have funding available for England, Scotland and Wales.

title: Re:fit programme
cat_header: A procurement initiative for public bodies wishing to implement energy efficiency measures and local energy generation projects on their assets.
detail_from_source:
The Re:fit programme can support public bodies in the development and delivery of schemes to improve the energy performance of assets. As a result, carbon emissions can be reduced, substantial guaranteed annual cost savings achieved, and income generated.
The programme helps by enabling organisations, such as local authorities, schools, universities, hospitals, leisure centres and museums, to implement retrofit projects and achieve large financial savings.

title: Collective for Climate Action
cat_header: Building ambition and action within the public sector on addressing the climate and biodiversity crisis.
detail_from_source:
A self-organised network of public sector employees working throughout the UK. Creating an inclusive community of people who want to use their knowledge and skills to combat the climate and ecological crisis through their work.

Time is very short for getting the solutions that already exist scaled up and bringing down emissions. Through emphasising and explaining the urgency and the capacity for truly ambitious action throughout government bodies, leaders can be emboldened to make the decisions that really count.

title: Local Government Association resources
cat_header: A wide range of support to help councils address the issues of climate change and environmental sustainability.
detail_from_source: Includes information on upcoming events, relevant publications and notable practice examples.

title: Climate Emergency UK
cat_header: Tracking climate emergency declarations and action plans across the UK. Includes links to inspirational resources, events and information.
detail_from_source: Across the UK, local authorities of all political persuasions have declared climate & ecological emergencies and are creating action plans to deliver on their ambitions. Climate Emergency UK exists to support them to do this by providing accessible information about best practice and providing a network where local authorities, activists, NGOs, business and local communities can work together.

title: Defra guide for local councils
cat_header: Aims to provide local councils and community groups, wanting to take action to adapt to climate change, with information on some of the future risks and opportunities.
detail_from_source: Provides guidance and practical examples of action that can make a real difference, including a number of case studies. Having a good understanding of vulnerability to our climate – now and in the future – is the key to resilient communities.

title: Local authority greenhouse gas accounting tool
cat_header: Freely available and relatively simple tool for greenhouse gas accounting at local authority level.
detail_from_source:
Produces summary tables and charts to help local authorities understand their most significant sources of emissions, which can then be used to prioritise actions to reduce carbon emissions. Councils are also able to benchmark their emissions with other councils to understand how their performance compares with their peers.
The tool has been reviewed by the Carbon Disclosure Project for compliance, and can be used to disclose council emissions data to the CDP-ICLEI Unified Reporting System in the Local Government Emissions section. The tool is free to use for all councils in England. Webinar and presentations about using the tool are available here.

title: Council climate action plans list
cat_header: Searchable database of climate emergency action plans from councils across the UK, by MySociety and Climate Emergency UK.
detail_from_source: MySociety working in partnership with Climate Emergency UK developed this database to help collate information about council action plans. It allows councils to compare their plans and learn from others, and citizens to see what is planned local to them. You can follow the links provided to go directly to the online information available for a particular plan.

title: Local government climate change case studies
cat_header: A selection of case studies gathered by the Local Government Association.

title: Ways to engage digitally with citizens
cat_header: An overview of how different digital tools could help engage with citizens in decision-making relating to climate change.
detail_from_source:
This report shares lessons from Nesta’s research into some of the pioneering innovations in digital democracy that are taking place across Europe and beyond today. The aim was to address two main questions:
1) How and to what extent are digital tools being used by parliaments, municipal governments and political parties to engage citizens to improve the quality and legitimacy of their decision-making?
2) What can be learned from recent digital democracy initiatives about how to get the most from digital tools and create an effective platform for participation?

title: UK Citizens Assembly resources
cat_header: Archive of all the information generated for and by the UK Citizens' Climate Assembly.
detail_from_source: Contains videos and transcripts of all the speakers who presented evidence and opinions to the assembly, as well as its outcomes.

title: Councillors’ workbook on the local pathway to net zero
cat_header: Local Government Association support for councillors to play their crucial role in achieving the UK’s 2050 net zero target.
detail_from_source: A distance learning resource intended to provide councillors with insight and assistance with the key skills which will help them to be most effective in their role. Contains guidance, thought-provokers, case studies, hints and tips and links to other useful resources.

title: Community (town/parish) carbon calculator
cat_header: Combines public datasets and calculations based on land area and population to estimate emissions from each English parish.
detail_from_source: Gives small communities data on their carbon emissions that is easy to interpret, easy to share, and which gives them a clear idea of their main ‘impact areas’ – those big segments where concerted, community based action could really make a dent in local emissions. The information is displayed visually via a series of charts. Those who want to access the raw data can visit the downloads page to do so.

title: 31 Climate actions for councils
cat_header: An evidence-based and easy-to-use list of the most effective actions councils can take on the climate emergency.
detail_from_source: 31 actions are quantified in terms of their likely carbon savings, approximate cost and co-benefits. They also point to examples of best practice around the UK.

title: Climate action co-benefits toolkit
cat_header: Ashden's Toolkit helps local authorities build the business case for climate action by acknowledging the multiple benefits.
detail_from_source: Lays out how lowering emissions also creates improved health, social equality, thriving economies and community resilience. These wider benefits engage citizens in climate action – boosting public support for further change. The toolkit features case studies, region-specific data, and links to a wide range of resources, including reports and videos.

title: Rapid Transition Alliance
cat_header: Examples of where change has happened at speed as evidence that it's possible to address climate change at speed and scale.
detail_from_source: Drawing on inspiring and varied stories of rapid transition to show what kind of changes are possible, how people can help to shape them, and what conditions can make them happen. There’s no shortage of talk about the potential of greener technologies and long-term environmental targets, but change is needed now and a bigger conversation is needed on the immediate possibilities of rapid transition and more sustainable behaviour.

title: Climate emergency neighbourhood planning
cat_header: Guidance for policy writing and community engagement for low carbon neighbourhood plans.
detail_from_source: Explores the huge potential of neighbourhood planning to plan for and build a positive future for local communities, through addressing and responding to the climate and biodiversity emergency.

title: Doughnut Economics Action Lab
cat_header: Promoting transformative action based on the increasingly popular concept of Doughnut economics.
detail_from_source:
The Doughnut offers a vision of what it means for humanity to thrive in the 21st century – and Doughnut economics explores the mindset and ways of thinking needed to get us there.
First published in 2012 in an Oxfam report by Kate Raworth, the concept rapidly gained traction internationally, from the UN General Assembly to the Occupy movement. Momentum is building and cities such as Amsterdam have adopted it as a strategic tool for post-COVID-19 recovery, and a wide range of international thinkers have endorsed it.

title: Local green jobs (England)
cat_header: Considers the projected net zero jobs and the associated skills demands across England by 2030 and 2050.
detail_from_source: It is important local areas understand the skills gaps that will emerge within each low-carbon sector and, as a result, the opportunities for reskilling the workforce. This report comments on key areas of skill level gaps for each sector. For example, within low-carbon heat a skills gap to meet increasing demand will be in the design, specification and installation of heat pumps, with new jobs requiring NVQ level 2-3 qualifications. Within consultancies and financial services (part of low-carbon services), highly skilled (NVQ level 4+) demand is ongoing and required to ensure service sector organisations can exploit emerging opportunities.

title: Examples of local participation
cat_header: A global network and crowdsourcing platform for anyone interested in public participation and democratic innovations.
detail_from_source:
Anyone can join the Participedia community and help crowdsource, catalogue, and compare participatory political processes around the world. The Participedia platform is published under a Creative Commons license and is accessible and editable by anyone. 
For information on how you can contribute to the project, please see the entry-writing guidelines. Search, read, download, and learn from a database of cases, methods, organisations, surveys, teaching resources, and external data sets.

title: SME Climate Hub
cat_header: Tools and resources to support small and medium-sized enterprises to make and act on a climate commitment for the benefit of their business and the planet.
detail_from_source: Support in regards to measuring emissions, developing a climate strategy, and reducing both direct emissions and those in value chains. By making the SME Climate Commitment, your business will be recognised by the United Nations Race to Zero campaign, giving your business visibility in the community and with your clients. Financial and policy incentives coming soon.

title: One Planet Living
cat_header: Practical actions you can take to live within the planet's means to support life on earth.
detail_from_source:
As well as the four top tips of staying on the ground, eating less meat and dairy, lobbying your MP, and consuming less, there are links to information in the following areas:

Health and happiness
Equity and local economy
Culture and community
Land and nature
Sustainable water
Local and sustainable food
Travel and transport
Materials and products
Zero waste
Zero carbon energy

title: WWF footprint calculator
cat_header: Online questionnaire to help you evaluate your environmental footprint.
detail_from_source: A carbon footprint calculator created by the WWF with the Stockholm Environment Institute at the University of York, and the University of Leeds. Once you’ve answered all the questions in the quiz you’ll see the size of your carbon footprint.

title: Intimate stories of climate action co-benefits
cat_header: A collection of short videos produced to demonstrate the real life stories relating to climate action co-benefits: fuel poverty, air quality and jobs.

title: Climate action with your money
cat_header: Investment platforms, funds, pension funds, ISAs, lenders and insurers that you could use to help your money to do more good.
detail_from_source: “Even if the traditional banks, insurers and fund managers haven’t cottoned on to the fact that doing good with money can also be good for your pocket, there are enough providers out there in all walks of financial services competing to give a range of products that are good in every sense.”

title: Housing Delivery Programme design manual
cat_header: City of York Council's pioneering example of how to design and build better places.
detail_from_source:
Good design is essential for communities to thrive. It creates pride in place, participation, healthy activity, self-supporting communities, and safe and secure homes that improve educational attainment, mental wellbeing, low carbon lifestyles, and independence. This design manual has been developed to ensure that City of York Council meets the city’s housing need by ‘building better places’.
The manual provides a strong and ambitious design framework to support a progressive and collaborative programme which will ensure existing communities positively influence the outcomes. Creating a clear and strong set of design principles will allow the council to significantly raise the standards of residential place-making in York. They hope that their innovative developments will raise expectations and inspire others to deliver better.

title: Change the Rules
cat_header: Collection of inspiring projects and new policies aligned with a better future for all.
detail_from_source: Discover inspiring projects across the UK and the rules we need to change to build a better future. Change the Rules is a project from the New Economics Foundation to map local, community and other initiatives to build a more democratic and sustainable economy, and showcase the policies to make this happen.

title: City-level co-benefits research
cat_header: Findings of a joint research project on how cities are recognising co-benefits and raising their climate action ambition.
detail_from_source: Cities are at the forefront of the climate emergency. Home to over half the world’s population and accounting for up to 70% of global emissions, cities have a vital role to play in the transition to a resilient and low carbon future. By taking actions to cut emissions and reduce vulnerabilities, cities and their citizens can gain multiple co-benefits from climate action.

title: Futures Centre (Forum for the Future)
cat_header: An open source platform helping organisations and individuals consider 'what if?' questions about the uncertain future.
detail_from_source:
The Futures Centre, supported by Forum for the Future, helps put the uncertainty people are seeing in a wider context of change by:

tracking signals and trends,
identifying intervention points and opportunities,
enabling collaboration with people around the world,
providing easy access to a set of toolkits, reports, case studies and other resources aimed at increasing the ability of users to drive real change.

title: Unlocking the job potential of zero carbon
cat_header: We need to reduce overall energy use and ensure that all the energy we do use is from renewable sources. This will require the creation of a large number of new jobs.
detail_from_source:
The Green European Foundation, with the support of Green House Think Tank, has developed a model to estimate the number of jobs that would be created in key sectors of the economy, to not only demonstrate that a transition is achievable but to also show where those jobs will be.
This model has been applied to the United Kingdom, as well as to Ireland (with the support of Green Foundation Ireland) and Hungary (with the support of Ökopolisz Alaptivány). The methodology used in that work and its results are presented in this report.

title: B Corps
cat_header: Accelerating a global culture shift to redefine success in business and build a more inclusive and sustainable economy.
detail_from_source:
Society’s most challenging problems cannot be solved by government and non-profits alone. The B Corp community works toward reduced inequality, lower levels of poverty, a healthier environment, stronger communities, and the creation of more high quality jobs with dignity and purpose.
By harnessing the power of business, B Corps use profits and growth as a means to a greater end: positive impact for their employees, communities, and the environment. B Corps form a community of leaders and drive a global movement of people using business as a force for good. The values and aspirations of the B Corp community are embedded in the B Corp ‘Declaration of Interdependence’.

title: Courses in transformative change
cat_header: Learn new ways of understanding the challenges we face and ways to overcome them together.
detail_from_source: A free online course introducing a method called Theory U, for leading transformative change in business, government, and civil society contexts worldwide. u.lab will guide you in applying Theory U to an issue that matters to you, building your capacity to lead transformative change in the process. You will do so with fellow change makers locally and around the world. Co-pioneer new approaches to today’s most important social and environmental challenges.

title: Urban agriculture explosion
cat_header: Evidence that people can and will adapt and improve to new ways of doing things.
detail_from_source: With the rising awareness of the speed and scale of action needed to prevent climate breakdown comes a nervousness about our ability to meet the challenge. But one country’s experience at the end of the Cold War shows just how quickly people can adapt when they have to, and also that there can be unexpected benefits to making a rapid transition.

title: Local Energy options guidance
cat_header: Aims to help inform local authorities about the scale of opportunity available in the changing energy sector.
detail_from_source:
Outlines the benefits of a council-backed energy supply business and sets out a number of different ways authorities can get involved in energy, with examples of what some pioneering councils
have already achieved. Serves as a guide for local government, while also providing the building blocks for more in-depth thinking on the practicalities of setting up a new supply venture.

title: Electric bus revolution
cat_header: From small beginnings a revolution is underway.
detail_from_source: In 2011 the electric-vehicle manufacturer BYD Auto unveiled an early model of an electric bus at an industry conference in Belgium. The head of BYD in Europe, Isbrand Ho, later recalled in an interview that at the time the launch was considered a joke; “everyone was laughing at BYD – for making a toy”. Just eight years later, major European cities were committed to electrifying their bus fleets.

title: Sharing is caring
cat_header: Making the case for reducing overall consumption by sharing seldom used things.
detail_from_source: Sharing is one of the very first things we are taught to do as children – it’s almost the defining difference between being ‘good’ or being seen as selfish. But from the moment we become adults the focus quickly shifts in modern economies to everyone having their own things and protecting ‘private property’. Not only does this exclude people with little money, it leads to a lot of environmentally wasteful over-consumption as households duplicate often underused items. If we shared more in modern life it could cut waste and bring us together. Now a movement is emerging to rediscover the benefits of sharing.

title: Carbon independent calculator
cat_header: Quick estimation (without bills) or more accurate calculation (using bills) of annual individual emissions.
detail_from_source: Based around a family household where car travel is undertaken to bring in income for the family or to travel for family leisure, and carbon emissions for this and for energy use are then shared between all members of the household. If your circumstances are different you may need to adapt the calculator – for example enter the household size as 1, and share out household energy use before entering the data.

title: Climate Framework
cat_header: A cross-disciplinary initiative bringing the built environment and academic sectors together for climate action.
detail_from_source:
Underpinned by the vision and the mission of the UN Agenda 2030 and the 17 Sustainable Development Goals, the Climate Framework is organised around six overarching themes, together with a series of ‘common threads’ that are shared by all.
The six themes represent those areas that can be influenced most directly by those working in the built environment, and a curated library of relevant resources is provided for each theme:

Human factors
Circular economy
Energy and carbon
Ecology and biodiversity
Water
Connectivity and transport

title: The Carbon Project
cat_header: Bringing together leaders and experts from across the civil engineering industry to tackle some of the biggest net zero challenges.
detail_from_source:
The start of a long-term programme of collaborative work, which will seek to share knowledge and best practice on delivering low-carbon solutions across the industry. The work will be driven by a steering group of industry leaders and focuses on three workstreams where ICE can make an immediate impact:
1) Measuring, sharing and benchmarking of carbon impacts.
2) Capability building in low carbon design and delivery.
3) Identifying systems-level reduction in in-use carbon.

title: Net Zero Nation (Scotland)
cat_header: Sets out the Scottish government's overarching framework for engaging people in the transition to a net zero nation.
detail_from_source: Their intended audience for this strategy is primarily communicators of climate change. They recognise that government are not, and cannot, be the only ones who engage with the public on this matter. Addressing climate change will be a truly national endeavour. The Scottish Government wishes to work collaboratively and consistently alongside trusted messengers to ensure that the public are put at the heart of the national approach.

title: Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act
cat_header: The ambition, permission and legal obligation to improve our social, cultural, environmental and economic well-being.
detail_from_source:
The Well-being of Future Generations Act requires public bodies in Wales to think about the long-term impact of their decisions, to work better with people, communities and each other, and to prevent persistent problems such as poverty, health inequalities and climate change.
The Act is unique to Wales, attracting interest from countries across the world as it offers a huge opportunity to make a long-lasting, positive change to current and future generations.

title: Homes for people and wildlife
cat_header: How to build housing in a nature-friendly way.
detail_from_source:
Sets out The Wildlife Trusts’ vision for new homes that are inspiring and beautiful places to live, and where people and nature thrive together.
To achieve this, we need a new approach that puts the natural environment at the heart of development and planning. The focus needs to move to where and how we build houses, not just how many we need to build.
Imagine if the starting point for decisions about housing was to map our woods, meadows, parks and river corridors and identify where new habitats are needed – and then locate and design new housing around this. This is exactly what we need to do.

title: i-Tree
cat_header: A freely available tool to help value trees in urban and rural areas in relation to the wide range of benefits they provide.
detail_from_source:
A state-of-the-art, peer-reviewed software suite from the USDA Forest Service that provides urban and rural forestry analysis and benefits assessment tools. The i-Tree tools can help strengthen forest management and advocacy efforts by quantifying forest structure and the environmental benefits that trees provide.
Since the initial release of the i-Tree Tools in August 2006, thousands of communities, non-profit organisations, consultants, volunteers and students around the world have used i-Tree to report on individual trees, parcels of land, neighbourhoods, cities, and even entire states.
By understanding the local ecosystem services that trees provide, i-Tree users can link forest management activities with environmental quality and community liveability. Whether your interest is a single tree or an entire forest, i-Tree provides data that you can use to demonstrate value and set priorities for more effective decision-making.

title: User Guide for Applied Adaptation Pathways
cat_header: A useful guide for bringing the concept of adaptation pathways into practice.
detail_from_source:
The concept of adaptation pathways has been applied in many different ways. This guide was developed to provide a non-technical, user friendly overview of how to develop an applied adaptation pathway.
It specifies critical elements of an approach that can be used to undertake adaptation planning in your own organisation. While the approach described here is intended for implementation as part of a participatory process, it can be modified so that more quantitative inputs are used – thus enabling more direct guidance on decision making.
While developed to assist with climate change adaptation planning, the concept of pathways, and sequencing actions through time when external drivers are changing, can be applied to other areas of planning for long-term change.

title: Warrington Council Green Investment Scheme
cat_header: An example of an innovative way of funding an energy project.
detail_from_source: This project, which generates enough energy to supply a town, also demonstrates how local authorities can partner with developers to deliver projects that cut carbon, supply clean electricity, and generate millions of pounds for councils to fund essential services.

title: Absolute zero
cat_header: A research report showing how we can achieve absolute zero carbon emissions by 2050 using only incremental changes in existing technology.
detail_from_source:
We can’t wait for breakthrough technologies to deliver net-zero emissions by 2050. Instead, we can plan to respond to climate change using today’s technologies with incremental change. This will reveal many opportunities for growth but requires a public discussion about future lifestyles. 
Key messages for industrial sectors: Absolute Zero creates a driver for tremendous growth in industries related to electrification, from material supply, through generation and storage, to end-use. The fossil fuel, cement, shipping and aviation industries face rapid contraction, while construction and many manufacturing sectors can continue at today’s scales, with appropriate transformations. 
Key messages for individuals: travel less distance, travel by train or in small (or full) electric cars, and stop flying; use heating less and electrify the boiler when next upgrading; lobby for construction with half the material for twice as long; stop eating beef and lamb. Each action we take to reduce emissions, at home or at work, creates a positive ripple effect. 
Why this report matters: We are legally committed to reducing the UK’s emissions to zero by 2050, and there isn’t time to do this by deploying technologies that don’t yet operate at scale. We need a public discussion about the changes required and how to convert them into a great industrial strategy.

title: Preparing for a changing climate in local government
cat_header: Focuses on preparing for the impacts of climate change, for a wide range of officers within local government.
detail_from_source:
Local authorities have significant powers to influence how climate change is experienced in local areas through the decisions they make today. Authorities can address the risks highlighted in the UK Climate Change Risk Assessment (CCRA17) as well as use local data on population, and the latest national climate projection data (UKCP18), to prioritise areas for action.
This guidance:

identifies the steps local authorities can take to boost climate change resilience,
outlines a practical range of adaptation measures that can be taken and implemented by local authorities into corporate plans, policies and performance monitoring systems,
provides solutions for councils to support business and industry, and looks at how to protect our critical infrastructure,
provides measures to adopt in land use planning and the built environment,
advises on how to boost natural capital and build public health, social care and community resilience.

title: Zero Carbon Britain LinkedIn Group
cat_header: Professional networking in relation to Zero Carbon Britain.
detail_from_source: Accessible if you create, or already have, a LinkedIn account.

title: Totally Locally
cat_header: A free campaign for you and your town to use to improve the local economy.
detail_from_source: A well thought out strategic marketing campaign that has a timeline and covers everything from holding your first meeting, to launching Totally Locally in your town, to holding events, and much more. Then there’s loads of other tools to help you promote your independent businesses for a good two years. But the most unique characteristic is that it relies on ‘non-stucture’, good will, being nice, and having a bit of fun.

title: Regen: Transforming Energy
excerpt: A not-for-profit centre of energy expertise and market insight whose mission is to transform the world’s energy systems for a zero carbon future
cat_header: A not-for-profit centre of energy expertise and market insight whose mission is to transform the world’s energy systems for a zero carbon future.
detail_from_source:
Accelerating the transition to a decarbonised, decentralised and democratic energy system by working in three ways:
Pioneers
Getting cutting-edge projects off the ground and share the learning to inspire and enable others to follow.
Experts
Understanding the technology, finance and public policies needed to make sustainable energy work. By working out what’s wrong and how to put in right we can tackle the barriers preventing progress.
Convenors
Bringing the right people together to come up with ideas to achieve change that they can’t do alone.

title: Tyndall Carbon Budget Tool
cat_header: Provides a ready-made recommendation by experts at the Tyndall Centre for the ‘fair share’ of emissions reductions that each UK administrative area needs to be making to meet the UN Paris Climate Agreement globally.
detail_from_source:
The Tyndall Centre is a partnership of universities, bringing together researchers from the social and natural sciences and engineering to develop sustainable responses to climate change. 
Local authorities including Manchester, Sheffield, and Leeds have already piloted and are now actively using this online tool to set science drive climate goals based on research. 
The tool calculates a maximum carbon budget for the selected area, as well as a projected emissions reduction pathway, interim carbon budgets and average emissions reduction rate. It provides a downloadable PDF covering the method, results and recommendations for the carbon budget. It is also compatible with the SCATTER carbon footprint tool and CDP sustainability reporting.

title: SCATTER (Setting City Area Targets and Trajectories for Emissions Reduction) tool
cat_header: A user-friendly, local authority focussed emissions calculation tool, built to help create low-carbon local authorities.
detail_from_source:
SCATTER provides local authorities and city regions with the opportunity to standardise their greenhouse gas reporting and align to international frameworks, including the setting of targets in line with the UN Paris Climate Agreement. It is free to use for all local authorities in the UK.
The SCATTER tool

Generates a greenhouse gas emissions inventory following the Global Protocol for City-wide Greenhouse Gas emissions for your local authority area
Helps the understanding and development of a credible decarbonisation pathway in line with emissions reduction targets
Provides outputs that can be used for engagement to create a collaborative carbon reduction approach for local authorities

The tool now also offers the modelling of emissions reduction pathways to 2050, based on the ambition of several emissions reduction measures that can be set by the user.

title: Herefordshire Green Network
cat_header: Working to support Herefordshire’s local councils as they move towards a Zero Carbon Herefordshire.
detail_from_source:
Herefordshire Green Network aims to bring together local communities and share locally-relevant practical solutions in response to Herefordshire’s aspiration to be carbon neutral by 2030.
The website contains a selection of reading material and resources to help councils lower the carbon footprint of their community, and an invitation to Herefordshire councils to join the network and support each other.

title: Dancing Guy
cat_header: Amusing video illustrating the importance not only of leaders, but of the first followers who create them.
detail_from_source: Watch a movement happen from start to finish in under 3 minutes, and learn why it’s happening.

title: Demain (Tomorrow) film
cat_header: Meet the pioneers who are re-inventing agriculture, energy, economy, democracy and education.
detail_from_source:
Showing solutions and telling a feel-good story – this may be the best way to solve the ecological, economical and social crises that our countries are going through.
After a special briefing for the journal Nature announced the possible extinction of a part of mankind before the end of the 21st century, Cyril Dion and Mélanie Laurent, together with a team of four people, carried out an investigation in ten different countries to figure out what may lead to this disaster and above all how to avoid it.

title: Necessity
cat_header: A living archive rooted in environmental and social justice, sharing stories, learning and research from across the UK.
detail_from_source:
Identifies people, projects and networks that are contributing to the breakthrough of constraining powers of circumstance(s).
Explores and exposes the oppressive ties of these circumstances to seemingly inescapable powers and systems.
Asks questions concerning the indispensable, needed, required, or useful things of life.
Builds solidarity and collaboration with those that are being choked by current powers and systems.
Aims to fund those working within the following five areas: food systems and structures, radical reconciliation, decolonisation and post-growth economies, domestic resilience and creative communities, and environmental and human rights.

title: Top 10 actions for local governments
cat_header: Ten actions councils can take to address the climate and ecological emergency, divided into low or no cost, medium cost, and ways to raise money.

title: Recognising co-benefits of climate action
cat_header: Research exploring how action on climate change is relevant to UK public concerns, and associated government priorities.
detail_from_source:
Governments must decarbonise while meeting other key objectives, such as the provision of healthcare and public services and maintaining stable economic growth. The challenge of meeting competing objectives is often exacerbated by the nature of the political cycle, where key objectives tend to be traded off against each other.
This research draws on literature from multiple academic disciplines to explore how action on climate change is relevant to:

Health and the NHS
Immigration and security
The economy and unemployment
Poverty, housing and inequality

title: Project Drawdown
cat_header: Working towards the point where atmospheric greenhouse gases start decreasing.
detail_from_source:
Rigorously researched technical solutions to begin the process of stopping further climate change and averting potentially catastrophic warming. 
Project Drawdown conducts research and creates business Drawdown Labs and learning opportunities.

title: Bristol One City Climate Strategy
cat_header: A leading example of a city scale strategy for net zero. An extremely ambitious vision calling on people in Bristol to take part.
detail_from_source: In the One City Plan, Bristol committed to becoming carbon neutral and climate resilient by 2030. This strategy is a call to action, for people who live, work, visit and invest in Bristol to join in with a decade of transformation.

title: Manchester Climate Change Agency
cat_header: Setting out the city's plan, how it's doing, and what's going on.
detail_from_source: The Manchester Climate Change Framework 2020-25 is the city’s high-level strategy for meeting their objectives and targets. The Framework has been produced by the Manchester Climate Change Agency, on behalf of the Manchester Climate Change Partnership.

title: Nottingham climate action plan
cat_header: Nottingham is planning to be the UK's first carbon neutral city by 2028. Details on their plan and advice for citizens.
detail_from_source: The draft Carbon Neutral Action Plan builds on the Nottingham 2028 Carbon Neutral Charter by setting out high-level objectives in order to achieve a resilient and sustainable carbon-neutral Nottingham by 2028. The plan focuses on the actions the Council and others can start to take now.

title: Islington Vision 2030
cat_header: Plan for this London Borough to be net zero carbon by 2030. Sets out a vision of a fair and green future for local people.
detail_from_source: This draft net zero carbon strategy builds on work to make the borough a fairer place for everyone by helping with the cost of living and mitigating the inequalities exacerbated by climate change.

title: Campaign Against Climate Change
cat_header: Advice on getting your council to declare a climate emergency. Resources to push for a motion and to turn pledges into action.
detail_from_source: So far two-thirds of local councils (district, county, unitary & metropolitan) have declared a climate emergency. Check if yours has here and find more resources, including resources to push your council to pass a climate emergency motion and resources for both councillors and campaigners for the even more difficult task of turning pledges into real action.

title: Frome Climate Emergency Strategy and Action Plan
cat_header: Documents available that can be used as templates, and descriptions and information about how they have developed their plan.
detail_from_source: On 5th December 2018 Frome Town Council declared a climate emergency and committed to going carbon neutral by 2030. The Councillors also unanimously agreed to sign up to the Covenant of Mayors to track progress and link with towns around the world who are cutting emissions.

title: Cumbria Action for Sustainability
cat_header: Examples of practical projects to bring about a more sustainable way of life in Cumbria.
detail_from_source: CAFS have been running grassroots projects to tackle climate change in Cumbria for more than 20 years. Their projects tackle climate change in all sorts of ways – from helping people to make their homes more energy efficient through to supporting new community energy installations. They work with a wide range of local and national partners and funders to deliver their projects.

title: Place-based Climate Action Network
cat_header: Research council supported network translating climate policy into action ‘on the ground’ to bring about transformative change.
detail_from_source: Brings together the research community and decision-makers in the public, private and third sectors through five innovative platforms: three city-based climate commissions (in Leeds, Belfast and Edinburgh) and two theme-based platforms on finance and business.

title: Climate emergency: next steps – transport
cat_header: Focused on initiating action to avoid stalling in discussions about the perfect solution.
detail_from_source: Visible action by local government – the willingness to trial ideas and reinforce principles we already know have multiple benefits – should not await the development of a flawless, long-term strategy. Instead, these near-term actions should seek to inform and build momentum towards a collective, robust, and comprehensive response to climate change.

title: You’ve declared a climate emergency – what next?
cat_header: Sets out nine key stages for climate action planning, while emphasising above all that we need to begin now, and act fast.
detail_from_source: Intended to help break down the potentially overwhelming challenge, based on their experience of helping local authorities around the world to develop and deliver effective climate action plans.

title: 10 Point Plan to Fund Wales’ Climate Emergency
cat_header: Ten areas for investment where action needs to be prioritised and scaled up to meet the “climate emergency” challenge.
detail_from_source: This white paper has been informed by a range of experts and is a starting point for discussions with experts, public bodies, individuals and importantly the Welsh Government to set out what sort of investment they think is required to ensure we achieve our statutory targets.

title: Re:fit financing guidance from Local Partnerships
cat_header: An overview of the best financing routes that might be determined and incorporated into procurement for retrofitting.
detail_from_source:
Re:fit is a procurement initiative for public bodies wishing to implement energy efficiency and local energy generation measures to their buildings or estate and support services. This guide provides practical advice to help decision-makers identify the most appropriate financing options to support the decision to proceed with an energy efficiency or energy generation project and subsequent procurement. It comprises:

key considerations, such as borrowing rules, existing loan covenants, accounting treatment, VAT, etc – which can differ by sector and are subject to policy change
a description of the key features of each type of financing
key elements required to analyse projects to support the business case and, specifically, the
financing decision
procurement considerations for the finance element of a project, including setting requirements and evaluation of proposals
references to alternate forms of guidance where appropriate.

title: Rurban Revolution research project
cat_header: Two-year interdisciplinary research project focused on the transformative potential of urban greening and food growing.
detail_from_source:
Brings together expertise in ecosystems, psychology, plant sciences and supply chains from Lancaster University, Cranfield University and the University of Liverpool.
Will build an interdisciplinary evidence base on how urban green spaces and growing potentially influences:

Healthy and sustainable diets, by improving availability, access and consumption of fruit and vegetables.
Food production, in terms of quantity, quality and safety and the resilience of the UK food system.
Ecosystem service delivery, both inside and outside cities.

title: Flight free UK
cat_header: Flying less is one of the best ways to reduce your carbon footprint. Could you take a flight free year?
detail_from_source:
Reducing the amount you fly is the easiest way to make a meaningful reduction to your carbon footprint, and the good news is that there are lots of alternative ways to travel. With the whole of Europe on our doorstep, we have so many holiday destinations to choose from, and going overland can be a much more enjoyable experience.
It’s also about changing the narrative. Choosing not to fly can have an impact that goes beyond just reducing our own emissions. If lots of us do this together, we will make it normal not to fly, and show politicians and industry that people are ready for change.
Across Europe, we are seeing a rise in low-carbon travel, as more and more people choose not to fly. Could you join them?

title: Flatpack democracy
cat_header: Reclaiming local politics to drive local change. A practical guide and inspiration for you to steer your local council to thrive and prosper.
detail_from_source:
Since 2013 the Flatpack Democracy movement has shown that, by standing as a group of independent local councillors working closely together, people all over the country can and do steer their local councils to thrive and prosper, democratically.
Now, more than ever, we have the chance to refocus our local councils on what really matters to us and our neighbours. Flatpack Democracy is a practical guide and inspiration for you to get going.

title: Carbon Disclosure Project datasets
cat_header: Explore CDP cities and regions data. Search hundreds of data sets on local action towards a global sustainable economy.
detail_from_source: CDP is a not-for-profit charity that runs the global disclosure system for investors, companies, cities, states and regions to manage their environmental impacts. On this site you can explore their open datasets.

title: Good Homes Alliance
cat_header: Knowledge base and resource library to facilitate the development of sustainable homes and communities.
detail_from_source: The knowledge base has a number of useful resources for design teams, consultants, planning authorities and others – including case studies, guidance, reports, research findings, tools and more. Some downloadable content is exclusive to GHA members.

title: Carbon Neutral Cornwall Hive
cat_header: Cornwall's online community hub for climate action.
detail_from_source: Find out how you can help Cornwall become carbon neutral. Learn what other people are doing, be inspired by articles from guest bloggers, and share ideas so we can tackle climate change together.

title: Sustainability training for construction professionals
cat_header: Wide-ranging courses - live and on demand.
detail_from_source: Colab is a collaboration of partnerships, bringing together CPD and self-certified content to ensure that knowledge is shared and accessible to the construction industry.

title: Walk through a day in 2030
cat_header: "From What Is to What If" with Rob Hopkins - founder of the Transition Towns movement.
detail_from_source:
What if, over the next decade, a previously unimaginable transformation took place, sparked by Extinction Rebellion’s non-violent direct action and by the student strikes, the subsequent election of a government committed to deep transformation, the reorienting of capital and business, the huge mobilisation of communities across the country, and the creation of the conditions in which the imagination can flourish?
A remarkable time in history that future generations now celebrate in song and story. A time of guts, focus and wild creativity. What would it be like to arrive in that world?
Rob Hopkins, author of “From What Is to What If: unleashing the power of imagination to create the future we want” invites you to take a walk with him through a day in 2030.

title: Community Energy England
cat_header: Founded in 2014 by practitioners within the community energy sector to act as the voice of the sector.
detail_from_source: All work is intended to help clear obstacles, create connections between practitioners and stakeholders, and facilitate the work of community energy organisations – thereby benefiting the sector as a whole. There to help when issues and policy changes affect community energy organisations’ ability to create and implement projects.

title: Green Wedmore
cat_header: An umbrella organisation to co-ordinate, explore and encourage sustainable living as it could apply in practical terms to Wedmore and the surrounding villages.
detail_from_source:
“With man-made climate change now a virtual certainty as well as the unsustainable extraction of raw materials and water this community has three broad choices:

Rely on central and local government to legislate mankind and this planet out of trouble. 
Ignore all the scientists and evidence and continue to overuse energy, refuse to recycle, fly on a whim to the closest destinations and eat strawberries from Egypt in January.
Work together as a community to find ways to reduce our environmental impact.

We like option three. If you’d like to find out more have a look around our website and get in touch!”

title: Green Building Council
cat_header: Uniting the UK building industry using sustainability as a catalyst to positively transform the places people use every day.
detail_from_source:
A mission to radically improve the sustainability of the built environment, by transforming the way it is planned, designed, constructed, maintained and operated.
A vision of a built environment that enables people and planet to thrive by:

Mitigating and adapting to climate change
Eliminating waste and maximising resource efficiency
Embracing and restoring nature and promoting biodiversity
Optimising the health and wellbeing of people
Creating long-term value for society and improving quality of life

title: EAT Lancet report
cat_header: Report from leading scientists around the world on how we will need to transform eating habits, improve food production and reduce food waste to feed the world population within planetary boundaries.
detail_from_source: “Food is the single strongest lever to optimize human health and environmental sustainability on Earth. However, food is currently threatening both people and planet. An immense challenge facing humanity is to provide a growing world population with healthy diets from sustainable food systems. While global food production of calories has generally kept pace with population growth, more than 820 million people still lack sufficient food, and many more consume either low-quality diets or too much food. Unhealthy diets now pose a greater risk to morbidity and mortality than unsafe sex, alcohol, drug and tobacco use combined. Global food production threatens climate stability and ecosystem resilience and constitutes the single largest driver of environmental degradation and transgression of planetary boundaries. Taken together the outcome is dire. A radical transformation of the global food system is urgently needed.”

title: Charge My Street
cat_header: A community benefit society that installs and operates community chargepoints, raising money through community shares.
detail_from_source:
The lack of chargepoints where people need them is one of the biggest barriers to the electric vehicle revolution, a revolution that will help to reduce air pollution and control greenhouse gases.
Charge My Street’s vision is for every home to be within a 5-minute walk of a chargepoint, giving residents without off-street parking the opportunity to switch to an electric vehicle.

title: The road to low carbon heat
cat_header: Outlines the colossal challenge of decarbonising heat in the UK and what the challenge means for businesses, consumers and communities.
detail_from_source: Provides thirteen recommendations that will help address this challenge. The recommendations include policy steps the government should take in the short, medium and long-term. Looks at the technological solutions that are currently available and the further innovation that will be needed going forward. Stresses the need for local and national coordination on heat policy through a National Delivery Body, which has yet to be achieved. The National Delivery Body would be an independent, impartial body that would work with the government on creating, coordinating and delivering an overarching national decarbonisation of heat programme.

title: British Standards Institute – Carbon Neutrality
cat_header: Sets out the requirements for achieving and demonstrating carbon neutrality.
detail_from_source:
“Climate change strategy is critical to both government and industry. When implementing effective climate change mitigation measures, the ability to differentiate between real and false claims of carbon neutrality is critical. PAS 2060 can help you cut through the cynicism and doubt, and maintain trust in your efforts to manage and reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Plus, PAS 2060 applies to organizations of all types. This means you can achieve carbon neutrality across all areas, including buildings, transport, manufacturing, product lines and events.
Benefits of PAS 2060:

Meet customer, stakeholder, industry and legal expectations
Reduce greenhouse gas emissions and quantify your carbon footprint
Identify areas of inefficiency and improve overall performance
Make cost savings by reducing energy consumption and bills
Gain credibility with an accurate carbon neutrality statement”

title: Playing out
cat_header: A parent and resident led movement restoring children’s freedom to play out in the streets and spaces where they live.
detail_from_source:
Ten good reasons why children should be supported and enabled to play out in their local environment:

Children need to play
The street is a blank canvas
Children like to play near home and have traditionally done so
Children need ample space to play energetically
Playing in the street increases community cohesion
Street play creates new opportunities for socialising and friendships
Children learn valuable skills when they play out
Playing in the street allows for ‘semi-supervised’ play
The street is the “starting point for all journeys” (Tim Gill, 2007)
Streets constitute the vast majority of public space in the city

Playing out can support you to make changes where you live.

title: Bristol Climate Hub
cat_header: A place for discovering how we can all play our part in looking after the world, and sharing the stories that inspire us.
detail_from_source: Ideas, actions, and inspirational stories of people doing things differently – for individuals, companies and government.

title: Disappearing traffic? The story so far
cat_header: Research on the unexpected outcomes of reallocating road space to walking and cycling.
detail_from_source:
Reallocating road space from general traffic, to improve conditions for pedestrians or cyclists or buses or on-street light rail or other high-occupancy vehicles, is often predicted to cause major traffic problems on neighbouring streets.
This paper reports on two phases of research, resulting in the examination of over 70 case studies of road space reallocation from eleven countries, and the collation of opinions from over 200 transport professionals worldwide.
The findings suggest that predictions of traffic problems are often unnecessarily alarmist, and that, given appropriate local circumstances, significant reductions in overall traffic levels can occur, with people making a far wider range of behavioural responses than has traditionally been assumed.
Follow-up work has also highlighted the importance of managing how schemes are perceived by the public and reported in the media, with various lessons for avoiding problems. Finally, the findings highlight that well-designed schemes to reallocate road space can often contribute to a multiplicity of different policy aims and objectives.

title: Carbon Positive Project
cat_header: Information about the activities Natural Resources Wales is undertaking on its journey to becoming a carbon positive organisation.
detail_from_source:
The Carbon Positive Project is funded by Welsh Government to show leadership in how the public sector can reduce its carbon impact to tackle climate change.
They’re taking positive steps to reduce their carbon emissions, and to enhance and protect carbon stored on the land they manage.
Through sharing their experiences they aim to encourage further decarbonisation in Wales.

title: Doughnut economics in Cornwall Council
cat_header: Describes how Cornwall Council is using Doughnut economics to respond to the climate emergency in their county.
detail_from_source: Presented as part of Cornwall Chamber of Commerce’s Festival of Business on 5 November 2020 by Peter Lefort, Sector & Partnership Lead for Carbon Neutral Cornwall at Cornwall Council.

title: Post-COVID-19 county economies
cat_header: A report underlining the vital role that county authorities have to play in leading place based recovery and sustainability.
detail_from_source:
The report identifies four key ways in which behaviours have been impacted during the pandemic that will impact on future economic activity:

Home/digital working
Increasingly ‘local’ perspective
Reduced carbon consumption
Shift in consumer behaviour. 

Demand for new products and services is increasing, presenting opportunities for county authority areas, including: 

Town centres/highstreets need to be reimagined
New forms of tourism
Green recovery
New sectors and markets. 

Ten recommendations are made to address the challenges, support economic and social recovery, and address imbalances and inequalities across the country.

title: Exponential Roadmap
cat_header: A report explaining 36 solutions to cut global greenhouse gas emissions 50% by 2030.
detail_from_source: Articulates how far we have come and how far we need to go. Step by step, it charts how the world can move from incremental to exponential action – doubling the number of companies, cities and countries acting on climate, then doubling again and again. These are the exponential strategies now needed to cut emissions 50% by 2030 or earlier, then doing it again by 2040 and again by 2050. The roadmap is based on the the carbon law pathway.

title: Heterodox Academy
cat_header: Supporting open inquiry, viewpoint diversity, and constructive disagreement in research and education.
detail_from_source: “In order to address society’s most intractable problems, learners must weave together the best ideas from a range of perspectives. Yet, colleges — the intended training ground for the sort of creative and integrative thinking such problem-solving requires — have become increasingly characterized by orthodoxy in what types of questions can be asked and what sort of comments can be shared in the classroom and around campus. Professors and students alike describe the toll self-censoring and threat of social censure have taken on learning, discovery, and growth. For the sake of higher education and all the enterprises of life that await students after graduation, now is the time to dig in and fix what’s broken.”

title: The Truth Behind the ‘Magic Money Tree’
cat_header: A short article and video about how money is actually created.
detail_from_source:
The vast majority of money is created out of nothing by banks when they make loans.
The main problem with this is that the vast majority of new money goes into financial and property markets, boosting asset and stock prices, and making the rich richer. Very little is used to boost wages, create jobs, and invest in the things we need.
So there is a ‘money tree’, but the question is: can it be used more effectively? There is no reason why some of the money created shouldn’t be invested through the government into things society really needs.
There is a tendency for politicians to see monetary policy outside of their knowledge base, thinking it is just something to be left to the central bank. Monetary policy has impacts that are of enormous political significance, and it is up to Parliament to scrutinise the wider effects of monetary policy on the economy and society.

title: A civic plan for a climate emergency
cat_header: A discussion document for policy makers and civic leaders.
detail_from_source:
The document discusses how to build a 1.5 degree city, focusing on four action areas: 

Creating zero emission civic energy
 Creating car-lite, climate safe, socially-just mobility
Creating a new city ‘nature deal’ 
Creating city common-wealth

title: Carnage film
cat_header: BBC spoof of a future world where the UK has gone vegan. Older generations are suffering the guilt of their carnivorous past.
detail_from_source: It’s 2067, the UK is vegan, but older generations are suffering the guilt of their carnivorous past. Simon Amstell asks us to forgive them for the horrors of what they swallowed.
